content.question:
Sociologists studying the behavior of high school freshmen in a certain state collected data from a random sample of freshmen in the population. They constructed the 90 percent confidence interval <math alttext="6.46 plus or minus 0.41" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>6.46</mn><mo>Â±</mo><mn>0.41</mn></mrow></math> for the mean number of hours per week spent by freshmen in extracurricular activities.
Assuming all conditions for inference are met, which of the following is a correct interpretation of the interval?

choices.label: For all freshmen in the state, 90 percent of the freshmen spend between 6.05 hours and 6.87 hours per week in extracurricular activities.
The probability is 0.90 that the mean number of hours spent in extracurricular activities for freshmen in the sample is between 6.05 hours and 6.87 hours per week.
The probability is 0.90 that the mean number of hours spent in extracurricular activities for freshmen in the state is between 6.05 hours and 6.87 hours per week.
We are 90 percent confident that the mean number of hours spent in extracurricular activities for freshmen in the sample is between 6.05 hours and 6.87 hours per week.
We are 90 percent confident that the mean number of hours spent in extracurricular activities for freshmen in the state is between 6.05 hours and 6.87 hours per week.

content.answer: We are 90 percent confident that the mean number of hours spent in extracurricular activities for freshmen in the state is between 6.05 hours and 6.87 hours per week.

topic.text: 7.3: Justifying a Claim About a Population Mean Based on a Confidence Interval

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
